ebcic module¶

Exact Binomial Interval Calculator

This module provides functions to calculate exact binomial intervals and some of the approximated intervals, such as normal approximation, generalized rule of three, Wilson score intervals and so on.

This module also provides functions to depict their intervals.

When you use or publish the confidence interval obtained with the software, please refer to the program name, version, platform, etc, so that readers can verify the correctness and reproducibility of the interval with the parameters, n, k and the confidence level.

Example of the reference is:

“This confidence interval is obtained by EBCIC 0.0.0 on Python 3.”

The initial software is based on results obtained from a project, JPNP16007, commissioned by the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (NEDO).

THE SOFTWARE COMES WITH ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY.

Copyright (C) 2020 National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST).

class ebcic.GraProps(k_start=0, k_end=2, k_step=1, log_n_end=6, confi_perc_list=[99], line_list=['with_exact'], savefig=False, fig_file_name='intervals.png', leg_pos='auto')¶

Bases: object

Parameter pool class for graph properties.

Parameters

  • k_start – Start range of k.

  • k_end – End range of k.

  • k_step – Step of k in range(k_start, k_end, k_step).

  • log_n_end – Max of x-axis given by (3 k_end * 10^log_n_end).

  • confi_perc_list – List of confidence percentages, e.g. [95, 99].

  • savefig – Whether save the figure or not.

  • fig_file_name – File name of the saved figure where extension may include, eps, jpeg, jpg, pdf, pgf, png, ps, raw, rgba, svg, svgz, tif, tiff.

  • leg_pos – Position of legend in the figure. Choose from ‘auto’, ‘upper_right’, ‘upper_right_nm’ (no margin) ‘out_right’ (outside right).

Note

It seems that saveifg, i.e. plt.savefig(), in jupyter saves blank figure. In jupyter, drag and drop the displayed figure to a folder, open it with Paint app and so on and then overwrite the figure.

set_k(k_start, k_end, k_step)¶
set_n(log_n_end)¶
class ebcic.Params(k=None, n=None, alpha=None, confi_perc=None, warn_line_confi_perc=60)¶

Bases: object

Parameter pool class for Binomial and confidence.

This stores parameters regarding Binomial and confidence after checking them and avoiding duplicate checks and warnings.

alpha_to_confi_perc(alpha)¶

Alpha to confidence percentage.

Convert given ‘alpha’ in between 0 to 1 exclusive to ‘confi_perc’ in percentage between 0 to 100 exclusive after input check.

check_and_warn_alpha(alpha)¶
check_and_warn_confi_perc(confi_perc)¶
confi_perc_to_alpha(confi_perc)¶

Confidence percentage to alpha.

This converts ‘confi_perc’ given in percentage between 0 to 100 exclusive to alpha in between 0 to 1 exclusive after input check.

set_alpha(alpha)¶

Set alpha, i.e. (1 - (confidence percentage)/100), and more.

This also sets its corresponding ‘perc_confi’ (confidence percentage), Z_{alpha} and Z_{alpha/2}.

set_confi_perc(confi_perc)¶

Set confidence percentage and more.

This also sets its corresponding alpha, Z_{alpha} and Z_{alpha/2}.

set_k(k)¶
set_n(n)¶
ebcic.alpha_to_confi_perc_wo_check(alpha)¶
ebcic.alpha_to_za(alpha, sig_digits=- 5)¶

alpha to Z_alpha for one-sided test in normal distribution.

Parameters

alpha (float) – (1 - (confidence percentage)/100)

Returns

za (Z_alpha)

Return type

float

Examples

>>> alpha_to_za(0.05)
1.64485

>>> alpha_to_za(0.01)
2.32635
ebcic.alpha_to_zah(alpha, sig_digits=- 5)¶

alpha to Z_{alpha/2} for two-sided test in normal distribution.

Parameters

alpha (float) – (1 - (confidence percentage)/100)

Returns

zah (Z_{alpha/2})

Return type

float

Examples

>>> alpha_to_zah(0.05)
1.95996

>>> alpha_to_zah(0.01)
2.57583

ebcic.check_between_k_and_n(k, n)¶

ebcic.check_k(k)¶
ebcic.check_n(n)¶
ebcic.compare_dist(params)¶

Compare major probability distributions in a graph.

Parameters

params (Params) – Instance including k, n and zah (Z_{alpha/2}) where zah is set by giving either ‘alpha’ or ‘confi_perc’ to Params().

Examples

>>> compare_dist(Params(k=2, n=20))
ebcic.confi_perc_to_alpha_wo_check(confi_perc)¶
ebcic.exact(params)¶

Return exact Binomial confidence interval for the parameter.

Parameters

params (Params) – Instance including k, n and alpha (or confi_perc).

Returns

tuple containing:

lower_p (float): lower bound of Binomial confidence interval.

upper_p (float): upper bound of Binomial confidence interval.

Return type

tuple

ebcic.interval_graph(gra_props)¶

Show interval graphs.

Coloring rule:

  • Exact lines and the line for k/n for the same k are depicted

    in the same color.

  • If k_start == k_end, approximated lines are depicted in uniq colors.

  • Otherwise, all the lines per the same k are depicted in the same color.

Parameters

gra_props (GraProps) – Instance including k_start, k_end, k_step, log_n_end, confi_perc_line, line_list.

Examples

Show intervals for multiple confidence percentages. See ebcic.ipynb for more examples.

>>> interval_graph(GraProps(
    k_start=1,  # >= 0
    k_end=1,    # > k_start
    k_step=1,   # > 0
    log_n_end=6,  # max(n) = 3*k_end*10**log_n_end
    confi_perc_list=[90, 95, 99, 99.9, 99.99],
    line_list=[
        'with_exact',
        # The followings are approximation.
        'with_line_kn',  # Line of k/n
        # Available only when k = 0
        # 'with_rule_of_la',
        # Available only when k > 0
        # 'with_normal',
        # 'with_wilson',
        # 'with_wilson_cc',
    ],
    # savefig = True,
    # fig_file_name='intervals.jpg'
    ))

Note

It seems that saveifg, i.e. plt.savefig(), in jupyter saves blank figure. In jupyter, drag and drop the displayed figure to a folder, open it with Paint app and so on and then overwrite the figure.

ebcic.normal_approx(params)¶

Approximated interval using normal distribution.

Interval obtained by approximating Binomial distribution to normal distribution.

Parameters

params (Params) – Instance including k, n and zah (Z_{alpha/2}) where zah is set by giving either ‘alpha’ or ‘confi_perc’ to Params().

Returns

tuple containing:

lower_p (float): lower bound of Binomial confidence interval.

upper_p (float): upper bound of Binomial confidence interval.

Return type

tuple

Note

Normal approximation does not give good approximation for small n or k being close to 0 or n.

ebcic.print_interval(params)¶

Print exact interval as text.

Parameters

params (Params) – Instance including k, n and ‘confi_perc’ (confidence percentage) or ‘alpha’.

Examples

>>> print_interval(Params(k=1, n=10000, confi_perc = 95.0))
ebcic.round_h_up(x, sig_digits=- 5)¶

Round half up.

Round half up $x$ to the decimal point corresponding to $10^sig_digits$.

Parameters

  • x (int or float) – Input value.

  • sig_digits (int) – Significant digits.

Returns

The rounded-half-up number of x.

Return type

int or float

Examples

>>> round_h_up(123.45678, -1)
123.4

>>> round_h_up(123.45678,  0)
123.0

>>> round_h_up(123.45678,  1)
120.0
ebcic.rule_of_ln_alpha(params)¶

Generalized rule of three.

Interval of rule of $ln(lpha)$, i.e generalized version of ‘rule of three’. This can be used only when (k == 0 or k == n) and reliable if n is large enough, say n > 50.

Parameters

params (Params) – Instance including k, n, alpha (or confi_perc).

Returns

tuple containing:

lower_p (float): lower bound of Binomial confidence interval.

upper_p (float): upper bound of Binomial confidence interval.

Return type

tuple

ebcic.test_all()¶

Test of all or some of the above tests.

Higher ‘ret’ is more critical.

ebcic.test_for_z()¶

Self test regarding Z_{alpha/2} and Z_{alpha}.

alpha_to_za(), za_to_alpha(), alpha_to_zah() and zah_to_alpha() are tested.

Returns

0 for no error, 1 otherwise.

Return type

bool

ebcic.test_of_intervals(n_start, n_end, n_step, confi_perc, sig_digits=- 5)¶

Test of reliability of obtained intervals for given parameters.

Check if integral of outside of the interval is alpha for given k, n, etc and return 0 if it holds.

Returns

num_of_wrongs, the number of unreliable intervals.

Return type

int

Examples

See ebcic.ipynb for the parameters where reliable intervas might not be able to be obtained.

>>> test_of_intervals(
    n_start=1,
    n_end=1000,
    n_step=1,
    confi_perc=99.0,  # Confidence Percentage (90 <= confi_perc < 100)
    sig_digits=-5)
ebcic.test_warning_once()¶

Self test of warning once.

Test of warning once for the same setting.

Returns

0 for no error, 1 otherwise.

Return type

bool

ebcic.verify_interval_of_p(params, lower_p, upper_p, sig_digits=- 5, verbose=1)¶

Check the reliability of the given interval.

This checks, for given parameteres, if integral of outside of the interval is alpha or not, and so on.

Parameters

  • params (Params) – Instance including k, n, alpha (or confi_perc).

  • lower_p – Lower interval of p for the params.

  • upper_p – Upper interval of p for the params.

  • sig_digits – Significant digits.

  • verbose – 0: no message 1: show only errors 2: show always

Returns

1 if unreliable, 0 reliable, i.e. no evidence was found to consider them unreliable.

Return type

bool

ebcic.wilson_score(params)¶

Wilson score interval.

Parameters

params (Params) – Instance including k, n and zah (Z_{alpha/2}) where zah is set by giving either ‘alpha’ or ‘confi_perc’ to Params().

Returns

tuple containing:

lower_p (float): lower bound of Binomial confidence interval.

upper_p (float): upper bound of Binomial confidence interval.

Return type

tuple

Note

Upper interval seems close to the exact one, but lower one seems a little greater than the exact one.

ebcic.wilson_score_cc(params)¶

Wilson score interval with continuity correction.

Parameters

params (Params) – Instance including k, n and zah (Z_{alpha/2}) where zah is set by giving either ‘alpha’ or ‘confi_perc’ to Params().

Returns

tuple containing:

lower_p (float): lower bound of Binomial confidence interval.

upper_p (float): upper bound of Binomial confidence interval.

Return type

tuple

Note

Lower interval is not a good approximation for small k, i.e. it becomes higher than the exact lower interval, though it is better than Wilson score interval (without continuity correction).

ebcic.za_to_alpha(za, sig_digits=- 5)¶

Z_alpha to alpha.

Parameters

za – Z_alpha for one-sided test in normal distribution.

Returns

alpha, i.e. (1 - (confidence percentage)/100))

Return type

float

Examples

>>> za_to_alpha(1.64485)
0.05

>>> za_to_alpha(2.32635)
0.01
ebcic.zah_to_alpha(zah, sig_digits=- 5)¶

Z_{alpha/2} to alpha.

Parameters

zah – Z_{alpha/2} for two-sided test in normal distribution.

Returns

alpha, i.e. (1 - (confidence percentage)/100))

Return type

float

Examples

>>> zah_to_alpha(1.95996)
0.05

>>> zah_to_alpha(2.57583)
0.01
